Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: basic statistics knowledge, basic minitab skills, insight that we should always just defer to a statistician
I had never taken a statistics class before, so most of the topics I learned about were brand new. Having some statistics knowledge has been and will continue to be very beneficial!
Minitab
I only audited the course, the initial aim was to know how and where to look for if I encountered a stat problem
I developed analytical skills using Minitab and how to interpret data
A ton! I learned many different statistical tools to tackle ecological research. I also learned where to start when you have research you want to analyze, and how to carry through that process.
A thorough overview of probability, basic statistical methods including graphing outputs, an introduction to regression and analysis of variance.
Refresher on stats

I learned immeasurably more than I did taking an undergraduate statistics class. I feel like I have a solid grasp on how statistics is actually done in professional and scientific settings, and that I at least know enough that I can be conversant in analyzing the results of a study.
This course was very valuable in helping me understand the diverse real-world applications of statistics principles, particularly in the context of environmental science.
I feel like I have a much better grasp of statistics now
Different statistical methods and when to use which method based on data type.  And also just a new way to look at data and design an experiment in a way that the data will be useful.
I was exposed to the basic concepts and analytical tools utilized in statistics.
I gained deeper insight into the theory and application of environmental statistics.
Review statistics that I took previously.
The basics of statistical analysis, which has greatly expanded my ability to understand research papers and conduct my own research.

I learned a whole bunch of intro stats techniques, and how to interpret and understand them if I come across them in a research paper or report. I leanred how to use minitab to do basic statistics on the computer.
Statistical analysis and interpretation, experiment design
linear regression, probability, basic statistics,

I didnt have a good background in stats, so this was a great way to fill in that gap. I feel like I have a clear understanding of how to understand statistics used in papers, reports, etc., and can use basic stats when I need to.
A better understanding of analyzing data visually, as well as a more robust theoretical comprehension of what means to prove a hypothesis with the use of experimental methods.

I learned a lot about statistical analyses (what they are, how they work, and how/when to perform them) in this course. I also learned how much I don't know about statistical analyses, which I think is also valuable!

An applied understanding of commonly abstract topics. The professor makes a great job explaining in a way that people who are not familiar with Math can follow, and for those familiar with Math, he makes sure they really get the idea behind the concept.

I learned how to analyze data using statistics, which will be useful to apply to my interest in policy analysis. I learned the different ways that different sets of data can be analyzed and the reasons behind why each test is used in a particular scenario. I learned how to use MiniTab as well as how to pick and clean a data set.
didn't quite meet my expectations
Very well!
I thought there would be more extended projects.
Well exceeding expectation
It will help me analyze my research data. As a researcher, I wished to refresh my data analysis skill
Very well!
quite well
Satisfactory
This class went far beyond my expectations.
The skills I gained from this course exceeded my initial expectations.
Exceeded expectations
Well.
They aligned well - I would say I got out of the course what I wanted to get out of it.
Some of the material we covered did not feel as applicable to my work (namely probability), but I am really happy I learned more about data analysis and modeling.
This course aligned with my expectations.
Very well
I wasn't sure what to expect, but the course turned out to be much more practical than I anticipated.
They align with my expectations pretty well. I expected to have to memorize more though, and in this class we had to memorize very little.
Before class, I wondered how the lectures and topics covered for this class but actually this class was beyond introduction. The class covered useful tools for statistical analysis in practice.
pretty well aligned
Very well.

Overall, I think I got the level of understanding that I was expecting to get before the course started. I was very motivated by the light-style of Jonathan's teaching method, as well as the flexibility of his class hours and assignments
This course exceeded my expectations.
Very well, even though it's a very basic course it cover a lot of content
I wasn't expecting the class to cover the material so in-depth and to cover such a wide range of topics (from basic statistic to ANOVA), so in that way it exceeded my expectations.
The second half of the course aligned with my expectations.

strengths: covered a lot of ground (even though surface-level) in a little time, very accommodating professor
weaknesses: didn't really inspire me to take more statistics classes... made me feel kind of hopeless that I would never know enough to do a good analysis or project without the help of a "real statistician" - which may or may not be true, but it's discouraging when that's the overall narrative in the course. Would have been nice to at least learn about analyzing studies or reports so that even if we can't do it ourselves we can have an informed opinion about things that inform our work

The class was awesome! Professor Reuning-Scherer has organized the course in a flexible way that everyone can learn in the way that works best for them. The workload is very reasonable and every assignment aided in my understanding of the material.  The only minor weakness (not a big deal) is that we were sometimes behind schedule and assignment deadlines changed from the syllabus.
Good professor.

Strength: rigorous curriculum and planning

Weakness: none so far but the speed of the class is fast. It is something to anticipate
it is and on, working on problems in class step by step make it easier to follow and understand

Strengths: professor's knowledge, ability to engage, ability to clearly articulate concepts, willingness to take time in and out of class to answer questions
Weaknesses: Not enough practice utilizing the skills we learned. However, I doubt students want MORE work (I certainly don't) so I don't have a remedy for how to get more practice...maybe offer external "Jeopardy" sessions? Or instead of office hours one day, have practice time?  Also, all my work got graded with comments on Canvas on what I had points docked for, but whenever I responded with clarifying questions on Canvas, they were never answered.

while the depth of material and the pace of the lectures seem necessary for covering the topic, sometimes the rate at which we covered subjects in lecture was at such speed that it made it difficult to absorb what was important.

Great intro class. Jonathan does a fantastic job structuring the material/course progression, and provides resources for all different learning styles: engaging lectures (also available online, a nice bonus in scheduling flexibility), summary topic videos, super approachable in-person at office hours.

JDRS is an amazing professor. He is ceaselessly engaging on topics that would be otherwise boring, and is unbelievably smart. If i did the course again I would do the flipped class. 

Maybe including R tutorials for some of the topics would be useful since students are left to learn that themselves, but maybe that is outside the purview of this class.

The course was very engaging and made the material enjoyable to learn. However, it would be helpful if we had more opportunities to practice problem sets in class (in addition to the homework assignments).
The course was really well constructed and had a ton of ways to engage. I cant think of much that needs changed
I like the various resources provided, especially that the notes and lectures are posted so you can go back since the class is pretty quick-paced.  No real weakness I can think of.

The course does a great job providing students opportunities to practice doing statistical analysis and interpreting the results of the analysis. Having most of the questions be framed within the environmental sciences contexts made the course feel very applied and relevant. At times, I wished the course contained elements of teaching us how to utilize statistical softwares that are commonly used, because Minitab, while incredibly user-friendly, is not commonly used in the field.

The instructor is dynamic and engaging, and the material is important to learn. Some of the assignments can feel tedious, however, and the teaching fellows were not all prepared to effective. Many assignments went ungraded for months and the TAs didn't always provide uniform answers to explain concepts clearly. I would certainly suggest greater scrutiny in selecting the TAs for this course going forward.
Jonathan is a great professor and explains concepts well. I appreciate that he tries to make the course accessible to many different learning styles.

Sometimes, JDRS felt the need to go into the weeds when it was clear that the class wasn't following just because it was material that has been traditionally covered in statistics courses. Overall, however, the strength of the course was its practicality.
Strengths: homework assignments did a good job of teaching stats, lectures were as interesting as intro stats lectures could be, it was very easy to ask ofr help from the professor and TFs

The lectures were a bit overwhelmed throughout the course. In spite of weekly assignments, it's hard to understand about the course overall. But working on final project was very helpful to wrap up overall.
strengths were jonathan's lectures and the number of opportunities to visit office hours

I took this class almost entirely remotely to accommodate a scheduling conflict. It was very well organized and easy to follow. TAs were mostly good and it was really helpful to have a TON of office hours.

The course is intended to be useful for people coming from diverse backgrounds. What can be improved, in my view is the use of examples that are more related to socio-environmental topics. 
Also, the format in which the homework and exams are submitted on is not the most helpful one, neither as some feedback provided by the TA's . To really learn, I believe a "review session" should be organized in class and not only during office hours - which, by the way, should be scheduled to happen in a larger classroom and preferably separating undergrad and grad students.

I really liked the way this course was structured, and how Jonathan provided us with very in-depth course notes. I also appreciated that we could work on our homeworks in a group, since I found it very helpful to talk through questions and learn from my classmates. I also liked that our exams were take-home, since math exams have always taken me a very long time to complete, and I thought that our final project was a good way to culminate the course.
The course is really good.

There were many strengths, including the thoroughness of the material covered and the professor, who is really good at explaining the material. The assignments were really useful- particularly the final project, which brought together a lot of the material we had learned and allowed us to apply this knowledge to the real world. 
The weakness is that the class moved really quickly and some material therefore seemed rushed.
The flipped course with a smaller class size seems more conducive to learning.

it's basically the only option for an intro or refresher statistics course at FES, so take it if you think there is even a remote possibility of needing this type of skills (unless you're more advanced, in which case don't waste your time)
Begin the homework assignments early so that you can go to Professor Reuning-Scherer's office hours with any questions.  He is very helpful!
Be prepared with workload and to keep up with the class pace. However, it'll be worth it in the end

I would suggest taking the class at the beginning of your first classes as it will enable you to understand interpret research papers which may be a challenge if you don't have a statistic background.
DON'T FALL BEHIND. You get so much more out of it if you stay on top of it. There's not a whole lot of class time, but make room to go to office hours and any review sessions-- it's worth it!
ask for help early and often- make time to review lectures online when possible
If you want a great basic intro to stats, this is it. You will not find a better-taught class on the subject.
Take it! And at least try out the flipped class. Also they will need to search out other places to learn programs besides Minitab.
Great for brushing up on stats or engaging with it for the first time. Recommend
Keep up with the homework and take advantage of office hours.  And know that Jonathan is super approachable.
If you have already taken an intro statistics class, it probably is not worth taking this class.
Take the flipped course.  The lectures themselves are engaging, but most of the learning comes from actually doing the problem sets, so focus your time and energy on that.

If you audit (like I did), you won't get that much out of it. 
Jonathan is an excellent and engaging lecturer.
Great professor
Useful even if a student has already taken college statistics because of the final project and the emphasis on application.

In this class, it is easy to feel like you don't have to do anything. Make sure you stay focused because once you stop paying attention and going to lectures, the work suddenly becomes a lot more difficult. But if you do go to lectures and pay attention, the work is pretty easy and intuitive.
Highly recommend to take the class regardless of the programmes in FES. It would definitely be helpful in every environmental field work.
take it!
If you need to learn stats, take this course. It will be useful.

Turn in every assignment and try not to stay behind. Go to all office hours and manipulate the software as much as you can, so that you fully understand what you are doing when inputting data into Minitab/ SPSS/ R

I would advise most FES students to take this course, and to make sure they keep up on the material. I would also advise them to do the work ahead of time and take advantage of Jonathan's office hours.

I took this course in college so I was familiar with the concepts and I only audited the class. If you are taking it/are new to the concepts, doing the assignments and going to class is definitely necessary

It was an incredibly thorough overview of statistics and I learned a lot. I would say to make an effort to stay up on the material and not fall behind. The course moves very quickly and it was really easy to fall behind. The weekly homework assignments and the end of the semester project were really useful in cementing the things you learned during lecture. I would consider the flipped class if doing hands-on work is your style of learning.
Go to office hours.
